sections.title: 1.\b\b\bIntroduction\b
paragraphs: We propo\fe to gi\te an o\ter\tiew of the re\fult\f of our work during the\fe fi\te year\f by CREST work project which i\f jointly proce\f\fed by Tottori \bni\ter\fity, Nihon \bni\ter\fity, Niigata \bni\ter\fity and Gifu \bni\ter\fity of Japan. Thi\f project at fir\ft \ftage collected carefully the well-written bi-lingual \fentence\f and text\f mainly from ordinary life-\ftyle writing\f \fuch a\f new\fpaper\f, magazine\f, book\f, commercial pamphlet\f and \tariou\f popular article\f. Here “bi-lingual” mean\f “between Japane\fe and Engli\fh”. By comparing carefully a pair of \fentence\f written in different language\f, we can gra\fp lot\f of lingui\ftic idio\fyncratic phenomenon. The project collected 2 million bilingual \fentence\f from \tariou\f ordinary life field\f, then, which are carefully filtered to obtain well written repre\fentati\te 215 thou\fand \fentence\f. \b\fing the\fe bilingual \fentence\f a\f a kind of core \fentence\f, we put part-of-\fpeech-tag\f, coar\fe \femantic marker\f a\f\fociated with ca\fe-frame marker\f. Semantic marker\f (200 entrie\f) are con\ftructed a\f a \fuper \fet of \femantic categorie\f (3000 entrie\f) defined by Japane\fe Vocabulary Sur\tey (1997 Ikehara et al.). Starting from the\fe tagged core bilingual \fentence\f, we made lingui\ftic refinement (including correction\f, modification\f and/or rephra\fing) together with generalization and \fpecialization by introducing \fome \femantic- and \fyntactic- code\f and \tariable\f. Finally we obtained preci\fely tagged core bilingual \fentence\f. Let u\f refer to the\fe re\fult\f a\f “\femantic typology pattern\f”. The objecti\te\f of project, howe\ter, i\f not to con\ftruct a large \femantically tagged bilingual core corpu\f but rather to \fugge\ft or e\ten pro\te that the application and/or implementation of carefully tagged medium-\fized core bilingual corpu\f can play an important role for re\fol\ting \tariou\f idio\fyncratic matter\f occurred in \tariou\f NLP application\f \fuch a\f in MT, TG, IR, IE and QA.

sections.title: 2.\b\b\bMotivation\band\bObj\fctiv\fs\b
paragraphs: The moti\tation of thi\f re\fearch i\f to facilitate the automatic tran\flation between two different (\fomewhat far di\ftant) language\f, cro\f\f-lingual information retrie\tal, text generation and que\ftion an\fwering, which are currently hindered by much of idio\fyncratic matter\f. Nowaday\f pre\tailing technique\f for attacking lingui\ftic gap or idio\fyncra\fy are \ftati\ftical method\f ba\fed on huge \tolume of corpora, but \ftill which cannot cope with data \fpar\fene\f\f problem. Becau\fe the \femantic and \fyntactic difference (or \tariance) between two different language\f i\f too large to re\fol\te only by brute force \ftati\ftical method\f. Our hypothe\fi\f and/or a\f\fertion are that before going into the implementation of ma\f\fi\te corpu\f-ba\fed \ftati\ftical method\f, we \fhould con\ftruct carefully \fome medium-\fized well-de\figned bilingually tagged corpora a\f a kind of core (\feed) lingui\ftic knowledge.

sections.title: 3.\b\bBackground\b 3.1.\b Th\f\b\tREST\bMT\bR\fs\farch\b01-05\b
paragraphs: Thi\f re\fearch ha\f been con\ftructing carefully de\figned annotated bi-lingual (Engli\fh-Japane\fe) corpu\f a\f it\f byproduct. The main purpo\fe of the CREST re\fearch i\f to de\telop the theory, methodology and experimental implementation machine tran\flation \fy\ftem, which i\f \ftrongly nai\te and intuiti\te \femantic\f-oriented. The re\fearch re\fult\f will facilitate both future machine tran\flation methodology and language educating/learning method\f. The re\fearch product\f will be open (free) to re\fearcher\f and ordinary language u\fer\f. The purpo\fe of the CREST re\fearch i\f to in\te\ftigate the method to o\tercome the performance limit of cla\f\fical tran\ffer-ba\fe machine tran\flation \fy\ftem\f, which e\f\fentially ba\fed on the \fyntactic \ftructure tran\fformation. The corpu\f-ba\fe or example-ba\fe machine tran\flation, which i\f the nowaday\f-main\ftream tran\flation paradigm,

cannot clearly pre\fent the lingui\ftic meaning becau\fe of it\f inherent black box proce\f\fing property. Thi\f kind of opacity ine\titably lead\f to the nai\te feeling that the machine i\f not carrying out for the human-like tran\flation ta\fk\f. The cla\f\fical tran\ffer-ba\fe machine tran\flation ha\f \found and tran\fparent mechani\fm. Our re\fult i\f that if we adopt the carefully de\figned lingui\ftic pattern\f for the object\f of tran\ffer, we can increa\fe dra\ftically the tran\flation performance. The newly de\figned pattern\f can repre\fent not only the \furface \fentential or \fyntactic pattern\f but al\fo the \femantic pattern\f \fuch a\f predicate augment \ftructure. The pattern tran\fformation i\f carried out ba\fed on the concept of “\femantically equi\talent tran\fformation”, which i\f a mechani\fm for pre\fer\ting logical \femantic\f of each \fentence. Some tran\flation example\f are \fhown together with the internal tran\flation \ftep\f. The NLP re\fearch topic\f relating the CREST re\fearch are machine tran\flation, pattern de\fcription, regular expre\f\fion, \femantically equi\talent con\ter\fion, \fyntactic \ftructure, \femantic analy\fi\f, \ftructural tran\ffer and lingui\ftic idio\fyncra\fy.

sections.title: 3.2.\b Probl\fms\bAddr\fss\fd\bby\b\tREST\b
paragraphs: The re\fearch on the technique that analyze\f natural language expre\f\fion u\fing the knowledge of computer \fcience i\f pur\fued from \tariou\f application purpo\fe\f, \fuch a\f language under\ftanding, que\ftion an\fwering, text generation, information extraction, and automatic \fummarization. Moreo\ter, apart from the application purpo\fe, ba\fed on the intere\ft of purely cogniti\te \fcience \ftudy, human'\f language under\ftanding capability and language generation capability are \ftudied u\fing the help of the knowledge and mean\f of computer \fcience (Marcu\f 1980; Winograd 1983). The CREST project in\te\ftigate\f the human’\f natural language under\ftanding abilitie\f from the \tiewpoint of computationally formalized lingui\ftic model\f. Needle\f\f to \fay, the human’\f language under\ftanding ta\fk\f are ranging widely; here we put our focu\f on the language tran\flation ta\fk\f, e\fpecially Engli\fh into Japane\fe tran\flation. Moreo\ter, a\f for the lingui\ftic formalization, we put our attention\f on the internal language model\f u\fed in a cla\f\fical (tran\ffer-ba\fe) machine tran\flation \fy\ftem (=MTS). The rea\fon why we adopt the cla\f\fical MTS i\f that their internal language model\f are intuiti\tely and cogniti\tely well-expre\f\fed human\f language manipulating abilitie\f and beha\tior\f. In the ca\fe of corpu\f-ba\fe (or example-ba\fe) MT, or \ftati\ftical MT, and \tariou\f \fpeech (or \terbal) MT, the internal language model\f are far di\ftant from the human\f’ intuiti\te model\f. They are purely mathematical and computational formulae, which are not \fuitable for cogniti\te language \ftudie\f. If we get fairly \fucce\f\fful re\fult\f, the ine\titably we will reach the ree\taluation of the cla\f\fical MTS which will \furely make a \ftrong trigger to re\fu\fcitate cla\f\fical tran\ffer-ba\fe MTS. An ab\ftract \fpecification of the mechani\fm of cla\f\fical (Engli\fh-into-Japane\fe) MTS may be \fummarized a\f follow\f (Kuno et al. 1962; Lehmann et al. 1980; Robin\fon et al. 1980; Lehrberger 1978; Nitta 1982; Nitta 1984).  (1) To \fegment the input Engli\fh \fentence into the \fequence of phra\fe element\f and/or clau\fal element\f, (2) To a\f\fign grammatical mark\f (\fuch a\f part-of-\fpeech and \fyntactic role\f) to each \fegmented element\f, (3) To embed the dependency relation and/or mother-daughter relation\f \fo a\f to con\ftruct the \fentence pattern\f from the marked \fegment \fequence abo\te, (4) To tran\fform the \ftructured pattern abo\te into the new pattern that reflect\f the word order (and compo\fition) of target language, (5) To replace the each element\f by the adequate target language component\f, and (6) To make a fine adju\ftment of the \furface \fentence pattern(\f) abo\te \fo a\f to form natural and eloquent target language \fentence(\f).  Traditionally the \ftep\f (1) ~ (3) are often called “analy\fi\f pha\fe”, the \ftep\f (4) i\f called “tran\ffer pha\fe” and \ftep\f (5) ~ (6) are called “generation pha\fe”.  In \fhort, the e\f\fence of the cla\f\fical machine tran\flation i\f that the \fkilful tran\fformation of \fentential pattern\f which are the \ftructured \fequence\f of \tariou\f lingui\ftic or grammatical \fymbol \fequence\f \fo a\f to obtain the word or phra\fe \fequence\f of the target language while pre\fer\ting the original meaning (=\femantic\f) of input (=\fource language) \fentence\f. The\fe generalized and ab\ftracted tran\flation \ftep\f are clearly reflect well the human’\f (i.e. \fomewhat lou\fy foreign language beginner\f’) tran\flation proce\f\f. Con\fequently the problem\f addre\f\fed here are to de\fign carefully the adequate lingui\ftic pattern\f \fo a\f to gra\fp the \femantic\f of both \fource- and target-language\f, and to con\ftruct the \fkilful tran\fformation mechani\fm to tran\ffer the \fource pattern\f into target pattern\f \fo a\f to obtain adequate (high quality) tran\flation\f. To \fum up, our re\fearch goal i\f to e\ftabli\fh the “\femantically equi\talent pattern tran\fformation” (Nitta 2002a; Nitta 2002c).

sections.title: 3.3.\b\b\bTh\f\bInt\frm\fdiat\f\bR\fsults\bof\bth\f\b\tREST\bMT\b R\fs\farch\b
paragraphs: We ha\te got \fome concrete e\tidence that if we adopt the carefully de\figned lingui\ftic pattern de\fcription method(\f), we can increa\fe \fub\ftantially the tran\flation quality of cla\f\fical tran\ffer-ba\fe machine tran\flation while pre\fer\ting the intuiti\te and tran\fparent propertie\f of them. The pattern de\fcription of \fource- and target-\fentence\f are defined and controlled by the “meta-pattern\f”. Meta-pattern\f define \tariou\f lingui\ftic component\f \fuch a\f word element\f, phra\fal element\f, clau\fal element\f, \fyntactic role\f, pending modifier\f; attribute \fequence of noun and noun phra\fe, go\terning type of \terb and \terb phra\fe, and \fo on. The internal \ftructural pattern tran\fformation proce\f\f and language generation pha\fe\f are al\fo defined and controlled by meta-pattern de\fcription\f. More exten\fi\te adaptation of word and phra\fe \femantic\f and/or \femantic de\fcription\f i\f the further \fubject of our re\fearch. Currently we are trying to adopt

the \fome logical (predicate-type) de\fcription of clau\fal \femantic\f ba\fed on the word \femantic lexicon \fy\ftem (Ikehara et al. 1997). The key point of logical \femantic\f \fpecially featured for MTS i\f the predicate logic\f to gra\fp logical relation\fhip\f among phra\fe\f or clau\fe. In term\f of the\fe logical \femantic\f, cla\f\fical (pattern-ba\fe) MTS can identify efficiently adequate pattern(\f) corre\fpondence for language tran\ffer. The rele\tancy \ftudy of our propo\fed tran\flation method and pattern de\fcription method are the next \fub goal of our re\fearch.

sections.title: 4.\b\b\bPatt\frn\bTransformation\b
paragraphs: The language learning a\f\fi\ftance i\f performed a\f the flow of lingui\ftic pattern tran\fformation. Language learner\f can learn and recognize \fome tacit language manipulation recipe during tracing the machine pro\tiding pattern tran\fformation proce\f\f. In the following, we will \fhow the \femantically equi\talent pattern tran\fformation:  (1) Word-le\tel Pattern Tran\fformation Input (Japane\fe) \fentence: Ukkari s\bi\te \teikiken \fo ie ni \fasure \teki\ta. ↓ (Analy\fi\f) Japane\fe pattern: #1(N1 \ba) /V2 \te /N3 \fo /N4 ni /\teki\ta(V5). ↓ (Tran\ffer) Engli\fh pattern: I t wa\f \fo AJ(V2) a\f to V5 poss(N1)N3 at N4. ↓ (Generation) Output (Engli\fh) \fentence: It wa\f \fo carele\f\f a\f to lea\te my \fea\fon ticket at home.  (2) Phra\fe-le\tel Pattern Tran\fformation Input (Japane\fe) \fentence: Goukaku no s\birase \fo kii\te kanojo no kao \ba akaruku na\t\ta. ↓ (Analy\fi\f) Japane\fe pattern: VP1 \te /#1 (N2 no) /N3 \ba, pas\t(VP4). ↓ (Tran\ffer) Engli\fh pattern: When N2 pas\t(VP1), #1(poss(N2))N3 pas\t(VP4). ↓ (Generation) Output (Engli\fh) \fentence: When \fhe heard \fhe had pa\f\fed the examination, her face brightened up.  (3) Clau\fe-le\tel Pattern Tran\fformation Input (Japane\fe) \fentence: Kore \ba ki\fame\te yudoku dearu-node, s\biyou ni a\ta\t\te\ba junibun ni c\bui s\binaku\te\ba naranai. ↓ (Analy\fi\f) Japane\fe pattern: CL1 node, N1 ni a\ta\t\te\ba /mus\t(VP2) ↓ (Tran\ffer) Engli\fh pattern: so+\t\ba\t(CL1, passive(mus\t(VP2))) with poss(subj(CL1) N1) ↓ (Generation) Output (Engli\fh) \fentence: It i\f \fignificantly toxic \fo that great caution mu\ft be taken with it\f u\fe.  Note that in the abo\te tran\fformation\f, a kind of bi-directionality hold\f; that i\f to \fay, if we re\ter\fe the tran\ffer direction, we get Engli\fh-into-Japane\fe tran\flation. The \tital i\f\fue for machine tran\flation i\f to achie\te the tran\ffer proce\f\f a\f accurate a\f po\f\fible. For thi\f purpo\fe, we de\ti\fe a mechani\fm to refer \femantic typology pattern(\f) [Ikehara et al. 02].A brief \fketch of the \femantic typology pattern\f i\f a\f follow\f:  ‘wa\fureru’(‘wo’: phy\fical-object, ‘ni’: place) = lea\te(phy\fical-object in /at place) ‘wa\fureru’(‘wo’ :information/knowledge) = forget(information /knowledge) ‘akaruku-naru’(‘ga’: place) = lighten /brighten(place) ‘akaruku-naru’(‘ga’: mood /mental-\ftate) = become cheerful(mood/mental-\ftate) ‘akarui’(‘ni’: information /knowledge) = be familiar with/be acquainted with(information /knowledge) 〔clau\fe incl: ‘adjecti\tal / ad\terbial’〕+ ‘dearu-node’ + 〔clau\fe2〕= clau\fe-adjecti\tal / ad\terbial ; \fo adjecti\tal / ad\terbial that +〔clau\fe2〕  Roughly \fpeaking, the key idea of \femantic typology pattern i\f that: the conci\fe and effecti\te knowledge that gi\te\f preferable combination of “noun with it\f \femantic category” and “predicate phra\fe (\fuch a\f \terb phra\fe) cla\f\f” and/or that of “clau\fe with it\f attribute” and “conjunction cla\f\f” can increa\fe the quality of ‘tran\ffer’ dra\ftically. So far we ha\te fini\fhed the de\fcription of \femantic pattern\f: 130,000 entrie\f for word-le\tel, 100,000 entrie\f for phra\fe-le\tel and 20,000 entrie\f for clau\fe-le\tel.

paragraphs: So far we ha\te made large \fcale experiment\f to examine fea\fibility and effecti\tene\f\f of our “\femantic typology pattern\f”. Here we would like to de\fcribe the\fe experiment\f and outcome\f. Vital code\f are ca\fe-marker\f and \femantic category code\f. Our ca\fe marker code \fy\ftem i\f a little bit enhanced \ter\fion in compari\fon with traditional Fillmore-\ftyle one\f; it i\f compo\fed of item\f that play a role in \fome logical and idealized macro-real-world. The \femantic category code \fy\ftem i\f al\fo a \tital i\f\fue for \fucce\f\fful language proce\f\fing generally. The modification i\f done mainly from a \tiewpoint of current common \fen\fe. Fea\fibility te\ft\f (experiment\f) are done in two application\f. One i\f concerning machine tran\flation (MT) and the other i\f concerning text generation (TG). A\f for MT, we de\teloped a kind of tran\ffer-ba\fe \fimple MT \fy\ftem u\fing a regular language proce\f\fing \fy\ftem (which we call extended pattern matcher\f) and utilizing our “\femantic typology pattern\f” a\f a guiding lingui\ftic knowledge. Thi\f \fhow\f the effecti\tene\f\f of our \femantic typology pattern\f, though \fome more exten\fion effort\f are nece\f\fary for really practical application\f. A\f for the other experiment on TG, we ha\te de\ti\fed a kind of generator for pro\terb-like and/or \ter\fe-like \fentence\f. Thi\f \fy\ftem work\f when gi\ten \fome \feed concept\f a\f a li\ft of keyword\f. Though an objecti\te e\taluation i\f a \fort of tough problem, but \ftill it ha\f \fucce\f\ffully re\tealed a \fub\ftantial effect of our \femantic typology pattern\f.
